response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}
<<<explanation>>>: You're creating a new dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator() in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the foreach inside the loop.

Regarding your second question, you can use a HashSet to remove duplicates from the list and then add the unique elements back to the list. Here's an example:
<<<code>>>: HashSet<String> set = new HashSet<String>();
set.addAll(names);
names.clear();
names.addAll(set);
<<<explanation>>>: This will create a HashSet of the strings in the list, remove duplicates, and then add the unique elements back to the list.
